segment.source: Describes the steps needed to ensure your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app is usable when a high-contrast theme is active.
segment.target: Describes the steps needed to ensure your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app is usable when a high-contrast theme is active.

segment.source: High-contrast themes
segment.target: High-contrast themes

segment.source: High-contrast themes
segment.target: High-contrast themes

segment.source: Describes the steps needed to ensure your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app is usable when a high-contrast theme is active.
segment.target: Describes the steps needed to ensure your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app is usable when a high-contrast theme is active.

segment.source: A UWP app supports high-contrast themes by default.
segment.target: A UWP app supports high-contrast themes by default.

segment.source: If a user has chosen that they want the system to use a high-contrast theme from system settings or accessibility tools, the framework automatically uses colors and style settings that produce a high-contrast layout and rendering for controls and components in the UI.
segment.target: If a user has chosen that they want the system to use a high-contrast theme from system settings or accessibility tools, the framework automatically uses colors and style settings that produce a high-contrast layout and rendering for controls and components in the UI.

segment.source: This default support is based on using the default themes and templates.
segment.target: This default support is based on using the default themes and templates.

segment.source: These themes and templates make references to system colors as resource definitions, and the resource sources change automatically when the system is using a high-contrast mode.
segment.target: These themes and templates make references to system colors as resource definitions, and the resource sources change automatically when the system is using a high-contrast mode.

segment.source: However, if you use custom templates, themes, and styles for your control, be careful that you do not disable the built-in support for high contrast.
segment.target: However, if you use custom templates, themes, and styles for your control, be careful that you do not disable the built-in support for high contrast.

segment.source: If you use one of the XAML designers for Microsoft Visual Studio for styling, the designer generates a separate, high-contrast theme alongside the primary theme whenever you define a template that is significantly different from the default template.
segment.target: If you use one of the XAML designers for Microsoft Visual Studio for styling, the designer generates a separate, high-contrast theme alongside the primary theme whenever you define a template that is significantly different from the default template.

segment.source: The separate theme dictionaries go into the ThemeDictionaries collection, a dedicated property of a ResourceDictionary element.
segment.target: The separate theme dictionaries go into the ThemeDictionaries collection, a dedicated property of a ResourceDictionary element.

segment.source: For more info on themes and control templates, see Quickstart: Control templates.
segment.target: For more info on themes and control templates, see Quickstart: Control templates.

segment.source: It's often very informative to look at the XAML resource dictionaries and themes for specific controls and see how the themes are constructed and how they reference resources that are similar but different for each possible high-contrast setting.
segment.target: It's often very informative to look at the XAML resource dictionaries and themes for specific controls and see how the themes are constructed and how they reference resources that are similar but different for each possible high-contrast setting.

segment.source: Theme dictionaries
segment.target: Theme dictionaries

segment.source: When you need to change a color from its system default or need to add images as decoration, such as a background image, create a ThemeDictionaries collection for your app.
segment.target: When you need to change a color from its system default or need to add images as decoration, such as a background image, create a ThemeDictionaries collection for your app.

segment.source: Start by creating the proper plumbing, if it doesn't already exist.
segment.target: Start by creating the proper plumbing, if it doesn't already exist.

segment.source: In App.xaml, create a ThemeDictionaries collection :
segment.target: In App.xaml, create a ThemeDictionaries collection :

segment.source: HighContrast is not the only available key name.
segment.target: HighContrast is not the only available key name.

segment.source: There's also HighContrastBlack, HighContrastWhite, and HighContrastCustom.
segment.target: There's also HighContrastBlack, HighContrastWhite, and HighContrastCustom.

segment.source: In most cases, HighContrast is all you need.
segment.target: In most cases, HighContrast is all you need.

segment.source: In Default, create the type of Brush you need, usually a SolidColorBrush.
segment.target: In Default, create the type of Brush you need, usually a SolidColorBrush.

segment.source: Give it a x:Key name specific to what it is being used for:
segment.target: Give it a x:Key name specific to what it is being used for:

segment.source: Assign the Color you want for it:
segment.target: Assign the Color you want for it:

segment.source: Copy that Brush into HighContrast :
segment.target: Copy that Brush into HighContrast :

segment.source: Determine what color your Brush should be and modify it in HighContrast.
segment.target: Determine what color your Brush should be and modify it in HighContrast.

segment.source: Determining a color for high contrast requires a bit of learning.
segment.target: Determining a color for high contrast requires a bit of learning.

segment.source: The plumbing you've created above makes it easy to update.
segment.target: The plumbing you've created above makes it easy to update.

segment.source: High-contrast colors
segment.target: High-contrast colors

segment.source: Users can switch to high-contrast using the settings page.
segment.target: Users can switch to high-contrast using the settings page.

segment.source: There are 4 high-contrast themes by default.
segment.target: There are 4 high-contrast themes by default.

segment.source: Once the user selects an option, the page shows a preview of how apps will likely look.
segment.target: Once the user selects an option, the page shows a preview of how apps will likely look.

segment.source: High-contrast settings
segment.target: High-contrast settings

segment.source: High-contrast settings
segment.target: High-contrast settings

segment.source: Every square on the preview can be clicked to change its value.
segment.target: Every square on the preview can be clicked to change its value.

segment.source: Every square also directly maps to a system resource.
segment.target: Every square also directly maps to a system resource.

segment.source: High-contrast resources
segment.target: High-contrast resources

segment.source: High-contrast resources
segment.target: High-contrast resources

segment.source: If you prefix the names called out above with SystemColor and postfix them with Color, for example: SystemColorWindowTextColor, these will dynamically update to match what the user specified.
segment.target: If you prefix the names called out above with SystemColor and postfix them with Color, for example: SystemColorWindowTextColor, these will dynamically update to match what the user specified.

segment.source: This frees you from having to pick a specific color for high contrast.
segment.target: This frees you from having to pick a specific color for high contrast.

segment.source: Instead, pick a system resource that corresponds to what the color is being used for.
segment.target: Instead, pick a system resource that corresponds to what the color is being used for.

segment.source: In the above example, we named our page background color to be SolidColorBrushBrandedPageBackground.
segment.target: In the above example, we named our page background color to be SolidColorBrushBrandedPageBackground.

segment.source: Since this will be used for a background, we can map this to the SystemColorWindowColor in high contrast:
segment.target: Since this will be used for a background, we can map this to the SystemColorWindowColor in high contrast:

segment.source: If you stick to the palette of 8 high contrast colors, you don't have to create any additional high contrast ResourceDictionaries.
segment.target: If you stick to the palette of 8 high contrast colors, you don't have to create any additional high contrast ResourceDictionaries.

segment.source: This limited palette can often present difficult challenges in representing complex visual states.
segment.target: This limited palette can often present difficult challenges in representing complex visual states.

segment.source: Often, adding a border to an area only in high contrast can help clarify a situation.
segment.target: Often, adding a border to an area only in high contrast can help clarify a situation.

segment.source: DO's and DON'Ts
segment.target: DO's and DON'Ts

segment.source: DO test in high-contrast mode early and often.
segment.target: DO test in high-contrast mode early and often.

segment.source: DO use the named colors for their intended purpose.
segment.target: DO use the named colors for their intended purpose.

segment.source: DO put primitives like Color, Brush, and Thickness inside of ThemeDictionaries.
segment.target: DO put primitives like Color, Brush, and Thickness inside of ThemeDictionaries.

segment.source: Avoid putting more complex resources like Style elements in them.
segment.target: Avoid putting more complex resources like Style elements in them.

segment.source: The following example works fine:
segment.target: The following example works fine:

segment.source: DO use high-contrast foreground colors for foreground UI elements.
segment.target: DO use high-contrast foreground colors for foreground UI elements.

segment.source: DO use high-contrast colors with their defined color pair.
segment.target: DO use high-contrast colors with their defined color pair.

segment.source: For example, always use BUTTONTEXT with BUTTONFACE, especially in a foreground/background situation.
segment.target: For example, always use BUTTONTEXT with BUTTONFACE, especially in a foreground/background situation.

segment.source: DO use the recommended high-contrast color pairing for a particular UI element to ensure the required 14:1 contrast ratio is met.
segment.target: DO use the recommended high-contrast color pairing for a particular UI element to ensure the required 14:1 contrast ratio is met.

segment.source: DON'T break apart high-contrast color pairs or arbitrarily mix and match high-contrast colors.
segment.target: DON'T break apart high-contrast color pairs or arbitrarily mix and match high-contrast colors.

segment.source: This will often create invisible UI for at least one of the pre-installed high contrast themes.
segment.target: This will often create invisible UI for at least one of the pre-installed high contrast themes.

segment.source: DON'T put any Brush objects that you create outside a ThemeDictionaries collection.
segment.target: DON'T put any Brush objects that you create outside a ThemeDictionaries collection.

segment.source: DON'T ever use StaticResource to reference a resource in a ThemeDictionaries collection.
segment.target: DON'T ever use StaticResource to reference a resource in a ThemeDictionaries collection.

segment.source: This will appear to work until the user changes themes while your app is running.
segment.target: This will appear to work until the user changes themes while your app is running.

segment.source: Use ThemeResource instead.
segment.target: Use ThemeResource instead.

segment.source: DON'T use hard coded color values.
segment.target: DON'T use hard coded color values.

segment.source: DON'T use a color just because you like it.
segment.target: DON'T use a color just because you like it.

segment.source: See XAML theme resources for more information.
segment.target: See XAML theme resources for more information.

segment.source: When to use borders
segment.target: When to use borders

segment.source: In high-contrast mode, add a borders to a UI element where it is necessary to keep a recognizable boundary shape on the item.
segment.target: In high-contrast mode, add a borders to a UI element where it is necessary to keep a recognizable boundary shape on the item.

segment.source: Use borders to differentiate between the content areas of navigation, actions, and content.
segment.target: Use borders to differentiate between the content areas of navigation, actions, and content.

segment.source: A navigation pane separated from the rest of the page
segment.target: A navigation pane separated from the rest of the page

segment.source: A navigation pane separated from the rest of the page
segment.target: A navigation pane separated from the rest of the page

segment.source: If a UI element does not have a border or background by default, do not add a border or background to the default state in high-contrast mode.
segment.target: If a UI element does not have a border or background by default, do not add a border or background to the default state in high-contrast mode.

segment.source: If a UI element does have a border by default, then retain the border in high-contrast mode.
segment.target: If a UI element does have a border by default, then retain the border in high-contrast mode.

segment.source: Overlapping or adjacent colors should be distinguishable from one another, but they do not necessarily have to meet the color contrast ratio of 14:1.
segment.target: Overlapping or adjacent colors should be distinguishable from one another, but they do not necessarily have to meet the color contrast ratio of 14:1.

segment.source: However, best practice is a 3:1 contrast ratio for these types of scenarios.
segment.target: However, best practice is a 3:1 contrast ratio for these types of scenarios.

segment.source: If high-contrast background colors are used to differentiate overlapping UI elements, the only guaranteed method for ensuring contrast between these elements is to introduce borders.
segment.target: If high-contrast background colors are used to differentiate overlapping UI elements, the only guaranteed method for ensuring contrast between these elements is to introduce borders.

segment.source: Detecting when a high-contrast theme is enabled
segment.target: Detecting when a high-contrast theme is enabled

segment.source: Use members of the AccessibilitySettings class to detect the current settings for high-contrast themes.
segment.target: Use members of the AccessibilitySettings class to detect the current settings for high-contrast themes.

segment.source: The HighContrast property determines whether a high-contrast theme is currently selected.
segment.target: The HighContrast property determines whether a high-contrast theme is currently selected.

segment.source: If HighContrast is set to true, then the next step is to check the value of the HighContrastScheme property to get the name of the high-contrast theme that is used.
segment.target: If HighContrast is set to true, then the next step is to check the value of the HighContrastScheme property to get the name of the high-contrast theme that is used.

segment.source: "High Contrast White" and "High Contrast Black" are typically values for HighContrastScheme that your code should respond to.
segment.target: "High Contrast White" and "High Contrast Black" are typically values for HighContrastScheme that your code should respond to.

segment.source: XAML-defined ResourceDictionary keys can't have spaces, so the keys for these themes in a resource dictionary are typically "HighContrastWhite" and "HighContrastBlack" respectively.
segment.target: XAML-defined ResourceDictionary keys can't have spaces, so the keys for these themes in a resource dictionary are typically "HighContrastWhite" and "HighContrastBlack" respectively.

segment.source: You should also have fallback logic for a default high-contrast theme in case the value is some other string.
segment.target: You should also have fallback logic for a default high-contrast theme in case the value is some other string.

segment.source: XAML high contrast sample shows the logic for this.
segment.target: XAML high contrast sample shows the logic for this.

segment.source: Make sure you call the AccessibilitySettings constructor from a scope where the app is initialized and is already displaying content.
segment.target: Make sure you call the AccessibilitySettings constructor from a scope where the app is initialized and is already displaying content.

segment.source: Apps can switch to using high-contrast resource values while the app is running.
segment.target: Apps can switch to using high-contrast resource values while the app is running.

segment.source: This works so long as the resources are requested using the {ThemeResource} markup extension in the style or template XAML.
segment.target: This works so long as the resources are requested using the {ThemeResource} markup extension in the style or template XAML.

segment.source: The default themes (generic.xaml) all use this {ThemeResource} markup extension technique, so you'll get this behavior if you're using default control themes.
segment.target: The default themes (generic.xaml) all use this {ThemeResource} markup extension technique, so you'll get this behavior if you're using default control themes.

segment.source: Custom controls or custom control styling can do this if you've used this {ThemeResource} markup extension resource technique in your custom templates and styles also.
segment.target: Custom controls or custom control styling can do this if you've used this {ThemeResource} markup extension resource technique in your custom templates and styles also.
